questions.text: Match the following types of cell death with their characteristic morphological features

A 32-year-old man presents with a slowly enlarging, painless cervical lymph node. He has no fever, night sweats, or weight loss. Excisional biopsy of the lymph node shows nodular architecture with scattered large, CD20+ CD30− CD15− cells surrounded by small lymphocytes. Flow cytometry reveals a monoclonal B-cell population. Which of the following is the most likely histologic finding in this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Large, multilobulated Reed-Sternberg cells within an inflammatory background

options.label: B
options.text: Small B cells surrounding “popcorn” cells in a nodular pattern

options.label: C
options.text: Sheets of large, anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei

options.label: D
options.text: Diffuse proliferation of centroblasts and immunoblasts with starry-sky appearance

questions.correct_answer: B. Small B cells surrounding “popcorn” cells in a nodular pattern
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Small B cells surrounding “popcorn” cells in a nodular pattern

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with pain in his fingers and toes, ulcers on his fingertips, and claudication of the lower extremities. He is a heavy smoker. Physical exam reveals cold, cyanotic digits with diminished pulses. Which of the following histological findings is most characteristic of this disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Transmural fibrinoid necrosis of medium-sized arteries

options.label: C
options.text: Segmental thrombosis with vessel wall inflammation sparing the internal elastic lamina

options.label: D
options.text: Pauci-immune necrotizing vasculitis with crescentic glomerulonephritis

questions.correct_answer: C. Segmental thrombosis with vessel wall inflammation sparing the internal elastic lamina
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Segmental thrombosis with vessel wall inflammation sparing the internal elastic lamina

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with intellectual disability, speech delay, and hyperactivity is brought in for evaluation. On exam, he has long face, large ears, and enlarged testes. Which trinucleotide repeat expansion is associated with this disorder?

A 16-year-old girl presents with easy bruising, prolonged bleeding after dental extractions, and heavy menstrual periods. Laboratory results are as follows: Platelet count: Normal, PT: Normal, aPTT: Prolonged and Ristocetin cofactor activity: Decreased. Which of the following best explains the patient's laboratory findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased cleavage of von Willebrand factor by ADAMTS13

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired platelet aggregation due to defective GpIb receptor

options.label: C
options.text: Deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor impairing factor VIII stabilization

options.label: D
options.text: Autoantibodies against Factor VIII causing secondary coagulation factor deficiency

questions.correct_answer: C. Deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor impairing factor VIII stabilization
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor impairing factor VIII stabilization

questions.text: A 35-year-old man receives a packed RBC transfusion for severe anemia. Within 5 minutes, he develops fever, hypotension, dyspnea, hemoglobinuria, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Cytokine release from stored leukocytes in the transfused blood unit

options.label: B
options.text: IgM-mediated hemolysis due to recipient antibodies against donor RBC antigens

options.label: C
options.text: IgE-mediated hypersensitivity leading to mast cell degranulation

options.label: D
options.text: Engraftment of donor lymphocytes attacking host tissues

questions.correct_answer: B. IgM-mediated hemolysis due to recipient antibodies against donor RBC antigens
questions.explanation: Ans. B) IgM-mediated hemolysis due to recipient antibodies against donor RBC antigens

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is admitted for severe postpartum hemorrhage and requires an emergency blood transfusion. Crossmatching shows incompatibility with all O-negative donor units. Which of the following is the most appropriate blood product to transfuse in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Only blood from another Bombay phenotype donor

questions.correct_answer: D. Only blood from another Bombay phenotype donor
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Only blood from another Bombay phenotype donor

questions.text: A medical student is performing blood draws for routine lab work and mistakenly collects a complete blood count (CBC) sample in a gray-top tube instead of a lavender-top tube. Which of the following will most likely result from this error?

options.label: A
options.text: Clot formation due to the absence of an anticoagulant

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of glycolysis leading to falsely low glucose levels

options.label: C
options.text: Hemolysis due to potassium EDTA contamination

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium chelation causing falsely prolonged PT and aPTT

questions.correct_answer: C. Hemolysis due to potassium EDTA contamination
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Hemolysis due to potassium EDTA contamination

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) presents with fatigue and jaundice. Labs show Hb: 8.2 g/dL, Reticulocyte count: Elevated, Bilirubin: Indirect hyperbilirubinemia, LDH: Elevated and positive Direct Coombs test. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism?

options.label: A
options.text: Cold agglutinin disease with IgM-mediated complement fixation

options.label: B
options.text: IgG-mediated opsonization of RBCs in the spleen

questions.correct_answer: B. IgG-mediated opsonization of RBCs in the spleen
questions.explanation: Ans. B) IgG-mediated opsonization of RBCs in the spleen

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. A biopsy reveals monomorphic small lymphocytes surrounding the germinal center in a mantle zone distribution. Immunophenotyping shows CD5+, CD19+, and CD20+ but CD23-. Which of the following translocations is associated with this disease?

A 4-year-old boy with recurrent pyogenic infections, particularly with Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pneumoniae, is found to have normal T-cell function but decreased serum C3b levels. Flow cytometry shows a defect in the complement receptor 1 (CR1) on phagocytes. Which of the following best explains this child’s increased susceptibility to infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Impaired formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC)

options.label: D
options.text: Failure to activate NADPH oxidase in neutrophils

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreased opsonization of encapsulated bacteria
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Decreased opsonization of encapsulated bacteria

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with recurrent abscesses due to Staphylococcus aureus. Flow cytometry with dihydrorhodamine (DHR) reduction test shows absent fluorescence. Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of this patient’s disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Deficient conversion of hydrogen peroxide to hypochlorous acid

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired production of superoxide radicals by phagocytes

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired production of superoxide radicals by phagocytes
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Impaired production of superoxide radicals by phagocytes

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with persistent mucocutaneous candidiasis, autoimmune hypoparathyroidism, and adrenal insufficiency. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the AIRE gene. Which of the following best describes the role of this gene in immune tolerance?

options.label: A
options.text: Induces T-cell apoptosis in the thymic cortex

options.label: B
options.text: Regulates presentation of peripheral self-antigens in the thymus

options.label: C
options.text: Promotes clonal expansion of naïve T cells

options.label: D
options.text: Facilitates regulatory T-cell differentiation in the periphery

questions.correct_answer: B. Regulates presentation of peripheral self-antigens in the thymus
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Regulates presentation of peripheral self-antigens in the thymus

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with fatigue, joint pain, and a photosensitive rash. She also reports a recent history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Laboratory tests show thrombocytopenia and a prolonged aPTT, which does not correct with mixing studies. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hypercoagulability?

options.label: B
options.text: Deficiency of protein C and protein S

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with progressive nephrotic syndrome, hepatomegaly, and restrictive cardiomyopathy. A fat pad biopsy is performed and shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light with Congo red stain. Serum electrophoresis reveals a monoclonal spike in the gamma region. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?

A 42-year-old man presents with dark-colored urine in the morning, chronic fatigue, and episodic abdominal pain. Laboratory results show: Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/Dl, increased reticulocyte count, LDH: Increased, decreased haptoglobin and Flow cytometry having absence of CD55 and CD59 on RBCs. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiologic mechanism underlying this disorder?

options.label: A
options.text: Complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis due to absent GPI-anchored proteins

options.label: B
options.text: IgG-mediated opsonization of RBCs leading to extravascular hemolysis in the spleen

options.label: C
options.text: IgM autoantibodies binding to RBCs at cold temperatures causing complement activation

options.label: D
options.text: Deficiency of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

questions.correct_answer: A. Complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis due to absent GPI-anchored proteins
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis due to absent GPI-anchored proteins

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy of Mediterranean descent presents with pallor, mild fatigue, and microcytic anemia. Laboratory findings show: Hemoglobin: 10.5 g/dL, MCV: 66 fL, RBC count: 5.8 million/µL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 21-year-old man undergoes colonoscopy due to a family history of colorectal cancer at an early age. The exam reveals hundreds of colonic polyps. Genetic testing shows a germline mutation in a tumor suppressor gene. Which of the following genes is most likely affected?

A 55-year-old male smoker presents with painless hematuria, flank pain, and an abdominal mass. Imaging reveals a renal mass with a solid golden-yellow cut surface. Histology shows clear cells with abundant cytoplasm and a highly vascular stroma. Which of the following genetic abnormalities is most characteristic of this tumor?

A 47-year-old man with a history of chronic diarrhea and weight loss presents with flank pain and hematuria. Urinalysis shows crystals and a positive cyanide-nitroprusside test. Which of the following mechanisms best explains his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased renal excretion of cystine due to a transporter defect

options.label: B
options.text: Hypercalciuria due to excess intestinal oxalate absorption

options.label: C
options.text: Urease-producing bacteria leading to struvite stone formation

options.label: D
options.text: Hyperuricemia due to increased purine metabolism

questions.correct_answer: A. Increased renal excretion of cystine due to a transporter defect
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Increased renal excretion of cystine due to a transporter defect

questions.text: A patient with a hemoglobinopathy was found to have a Glutamate to Lysine at position 26. Which of the following is the likely hemoglobin present in him?

A 32-year-old woman presents with sudden-onset abdominal pain and vomiting. Examination reveals guarding and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. CT angiography shows thrombosis of the portal vein. She has no history of liver disease, malignancy, or recent infections. Laboratory tests reveal: PT: Normal, aPTT: Normal, Fibrinogen: Normal, Prothrombin G20210A mutation: Positive. Which of the following best explains the mechanism behind her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased resistance of activated factor V to degradation by activated protein C

options.label: B
options.text: Increased circulating prothrombin leading to excessive thrombin formation

options.label: C
options.text: Deficiency of antithrombin leading to unregulated thrombin activity

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased protein C activity resulting in impaired fibrinolysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased circulating prothrombin leading to excessive thrombin formation
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Increased circulating prothrombin leading to excessive thrombin formation

questions.text: A 41-year-old male presents with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and dysarthria. MRI shows an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery distribution. He has no atrial fibrillation, no atherosclerotic disease, and no traditional cardiovascular risk factors. A bubble contrast echocardiogram shows a transient right-to-left shunt. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his stroke?

options.label: B
options.text: Fat embolism from subclinical bone marrow injury

options.label: C
options.text: Amniotic fluid embolism due to undiagnosed pregnancy complications

options.label: D
options.text: Paradoxical embolism via a patent foramen ovale

questions.correct_answer: D. Paradoxical embolism via a patent foramen ovale
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Paradoxical embolism via a patent foramen ovale

questions.text: A 48-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with progressive dyspnea, lower extremity edema, and orthopnea. Echocardiography reveals a dilated left ventricle with severely reduced ejection fraction. Endomyocardial biopsy is performed and shows interstitial fibrosis with scattered myocyte degeneration. Which of the following mechanisms is most responsible for the myocardial changes in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Desmosomal protein dysfunction leading to fibrofatty replacement

options.label: B
options.text: Mutation in β-myosin heavy chain leading to myocyte hypertrophy

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic mitochondrial damage due to ethanol toxicity

options.label: D
options.text: Extracellular amyloid fibril deposition within the myocardium

questions.correct_answer: C. Chronic mitochondrial damage due to ethanol toxicity
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Chronic mitochondrial damage due to ethanol toxicity

questions.text: Match the Following Proto-Oncogenes with Their Associated Cancers
Match the Following Tumor Suppressor Genes with Their Function Tumor Suppressor Gene Function

A 5-month-old male presents with recurrent pneumonia, otitis media, and chronic diarrhea. Laboratory findings reveal: Serum IgM: Elevated, Serum IgG, IgA, IgE: Absent or very low, Flow cytometry: Normal numbers of B and T cells. Genetic testing identifies a mutation in CD40 ligand (CD40L). Which of the following is the primary defect leading to this patient's immunodeficiency?

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired class switching due to defective T-cell help

options.label: D
options.text: Impaired formation of membrane attack complex (MAC)

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired class switching due to defective T-cell help
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Impaired class switching due to defective T-cell help

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion and chronic dry cough. He worked in a shipyard for 25 years. Chest X-ray reveals pleural plaques and interstitial fibrosis predominantly in the lower lobes. Which of the following histopathological findings is most likely to be seen in his lung biopsy?

options.label: B
options.text: Ferruginous bodies with prussian blue staining

options.label: C
options.text: Upper lobe nodular fibrosis with birefringent particles

options.label: D
options.text: Diffuse alveolar damage with hyaline membrane formation

questions.correct_answer: B. Ferruginous bodies with prussian blue staining
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Ferruginous bodies with prussian blue staining

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with fatigue, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, and hypocalcemia. Labs reveal: Low parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, Adrenal insufficiency and Circulating autoantibodies against endocrine tissues. A defect in which of the following processes is responsible for this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Peripheral anergy due to absence of costimulatory signals

options.label: B
options.text: Defective negative selection of self-reactive T cells

options.label: C
options.text: Failure of Tregs to suppress self-reactive lymphocytes

options.label: D
options.text: Enhanced antigen sequestration leading to loss of immune privilege

questions.correct_answer: B. Defective negative selection of self-reactive T cells
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Defective negative selection of self-reactive T cells

questions.text: Match the following.
Match the column.

A researcher is developing a novel cancer immunotherapy targeting a molecule that inhibits T-cell activation. The drug works by blocking a receptor expressed on T cells that interacts with B7 on antigen-presenting cells, preventing anergy. Which of the following molecules is most likely targeted by this therapy?

A physician is using a liquid biopsy to monitor treatment response in a patient with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). Which of the following components is most relevant for detecting minimal residual disease and treatment response?

A 58-year-old male with long-standing diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with progressive edema, foamy urine, and fatigue. Urinalysis shows: Proteinuria: 4.5 g/day, Hematuria: Absent and Microscopic examination: Fatty casts with "Maltese cross" appearance under polarized light.Which of the following is the most likely underlying disease?

options.label: B
options.text: Nephrotic syndrome due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

questions.correct_answer: B. Nephrotic syndrome due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Nephrotic syndrome due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and hemoptysis. Imaging reveals a centrally located lung mass. A biopsy confirms poorly differentiated small cell lung carcinoma. Which of the following genetic alterations is most likely responsible for this malignancy?

A 45-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia to both solids and liquids, regurgitation, and weight loss. A barium swallow reveals a "bird's beak" sign. Manometry shows increased lower esophageal sphincter pressure and absent peristalsis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Autoimmune destruction of myenteric plexus neurons

options.label: B
options.text: Fibrotic thickening of the lower esophageal sphincter

options.label: C
options.text: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) leading to scarring

questions.correct_answer: A. Autoimmune destruction of myenteric plexus neurons
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Autoimmune destruction of myenteric plexus neurons

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with chronic diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss. A biopsy of the small intestine shows: Blunting of villi, Crypt hyperplasia and Intraepithelial lymphocytosis Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 58-year-old male presents with severe headaches, cognitive decline, and seizures. MRI reveals a butterfly-shaped lesion crossing the corpus callosum. Histology would most likely show which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: Whorled spindle cell proliferation with psammoma bodies

options.label: C
options.text: Rosenthal fibers with eosinophilic granular bodies

options.label: D
options.text: Fried egg cells with perinuclear halos

questions.correct_answer: A. Pseudopalisading necrosis and endothelial proliferation
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Pseudopalisading necrosis and endothelial proliferation (Glioblastoma)

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a slow-growing frontal lobe tumor undergoes biopsy. Histology shows "fried egg" cells with perinuclear halos. Which genetic mutation is most characteristic of this tumor?

A 43-year-old male presents with painless progressive vision loss in one eye following a traumatic eye injury. Weeks later, he develops inflammation in his contralateral (uninjured) eye. Which of the following mechanisms explains the pathogenesis of his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of negative selection of autoreactive T cells in the thymus

options.label: B
options.text: Breakdown of immune privilege leading to exposure of sequestered antigens

options.label: C
options.text: Activation of self-reactive B cells due to defective apoptosis

options.label: D
options.text: Persistent antigen presentation due to defective regulatory T cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Breakdown of immune privilege leading to exposure of sequestered antigens
questions.explanation: Ans. B)  Breakdown of immune privilege leading to exposure of sequestered antigens

questions.text: All blood products are separated by centrifugation except:

A 65-year-old male with severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count: 8,000/µL) and mucosal bleeding is admitted for urgent platelet transfusion. The physician orders platelets from a single donor using apheresis. Compared to random donor platelet transfusions, what is the primary advantage of using single-donor apheresis platelets in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Higher platelet yield per unit, reducing the need for multiple transfusions

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased risk of alloimmunization against HLA antigens

options.label: C
options.text: Lower incidence of transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GVHD)

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased risk of alloimmunization against HLA antigens
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Decreased risk of alloimmunization against HLA antigens

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with multiple liver lesions and a peritoneal deposit, but no known primary tumor. A liver biopsy shows an adenocarcinoma with strong CK7 positivity and CK20 negativity. Immunohistochemistry is negative for TTF-1, CDX2, and PSA. Based on this cytokeratin profile, which of the following is the most likely primary site?
Which of the following is not true about Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH)?

options.label: A
options.text: Use of probes with fluorescent dyes applied to metaphase spreads or interphase nuclei.

options.label: B
options.text: Analysis can be performed on cells from chorionic villus biopsy or umbilical cord blood

options.label: C
options.text: Mandatory requirement of rapidly dividing cells

options.label: D
options.text: Detection of aneuploidy, subtle microdeletions and complex translocations

questions.correct_answer: C. Mandatory requirement of rapidly dividing cells
questions.explanation: Ans. C)  Mandatory requirement of rapidly dividing cells

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with a painless, mobile, firm breast mass measuring 3 cm in diameter. Core needle biopsy reveals stromal and epithelial proliferation without atypia or mitotic activity. The patient is reassured that the lesion is benign. However, she is concerned about the possibility of progression to malignancy. Which of the following histological changes would most likely suggest malignant transformation in a similar breast tumor?

options.label: A
options.text: Leaf-like stromal overgrowth with increased mitotic activity

options.label: B
options.text: Lobular expansion with dyscohesive cells and loss of E-cadherin

options.label: C
options.text: Increased glandular density with apocrine metaplasia

options.label: D
options.text: Stromal fibrosis with calcifications and collagen deposition

questions.correct_answer: A. Leaf-like stromal overgrowth with increased mitotic activity
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Leaf-like stromal overgrowth with increased mitotic activity

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. IHC staining reveals: Estrogen receptor (ER): Negative, Progesterone receptor (PR): Negative, HER2/neu: Negative, Cytokeratin 5/6: Positive. Which molecular subtype is most likely?
Which of the following conditions has the graph as depicted by the red line: Sickle cell anemia Autoimmune hemolytic anemia Hereditary spherocytosis Thalassemia

A 65-year-old man undergoing evaluation for suspected PNH is scheduled for flow cytometry testing for CD55/CD59 deficiency, along with a complete blood count (CBC), coagulation profile, and metabolic panel. The phlebotomist is preparing to draw blood. Which of the following is the correct order of draw to minimize sample contamination?
questions.correct_answer: B. Blue (citrate) → Red (serum) → Green (heparin) → Lavender (EDTA) → Gray (fluoride-oxalate)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Blue (citrate) → Red (serum) → Green (heparin) → Lavender (EDTA) → Gray

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with cirrhosis and esophageal varices is scheduled for a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS). His prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are both prolonged, but a thromboelastography (TEG) study is performed for a more functional assessment of his coagulation status. The TEG tracing shows: Normal reaction time (R), Normal alpha angle and Markedly decreased maximum amplitude (MA). Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to correct the underlying abnormality?

A 64-year-old man with serum creatinine 6 mg/dL and urea nitrogen 64 mg/dL undergoes a renal biopsy (image shown). Which of the following findings is most common for the underlying disease leading to this appearance?

A 45-year-old woman presents with a slowly enlarging, painless mass in the parotid gland for 3 years. Recently, she noticed facial asymmetry and difficulty closing her left eye. MRI shows a heterogeneous, lobulated tumor with areas of necrosis. A biopsy is performed, revealing a mixture of epithelial and stromal components with increased mitotic activity. Which of the following histopathologic findings would be most characteristic of malignant transformation in this tumor?

options.label: A
options.text: Perineural invasion with pleomorphic epithelial cells

options.label: B
options.text: Sheets of plasma cells and lymphocytes with fibrosis

options.label: C
options.text: Palisading necrosis and pseudopalisading tumor cells

options.label: D
options.text: Acellular amyloid deposits with birefringence under polarized light

questions.correct_answer: A. Perineural invasion with pleomorphic epithelial cells
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Perineural invasion with pleomorphic epithelial cells

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman has been a cigarette smoker since the age of 18, averaging a pack a day of unfiltered cigarettes. She has had several episodes of hemoptysis in the past two weeks along with fatigue, headache, nausea, and anorexia. On physical examination her sensorium is clouded. A chest radiograph shows an ill-defined hilar mass. A transbronchial lung biopsy is performed and the microscopic appearance is shown here. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this woman?
Match the Forms of Pyelonephritis with Their Distinct Pathological Findings
Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be observed in a patient diagnosed with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria?

A 35-year-old male with a history of IBD presents with elevated liver enzymes. On imaging, multifocal strictures and dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts are noted. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and hypergammaglobulinemia. A liver biopsy demonstrates onion-skin fibrosis around small- and medium-sized bile ducts. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A student was working on sarcomas in his Cerebellum Research Labs. Tissue was having strong nuclear staining for myogenin and MyoD1 and its molecular studies (including FISH) demonstrated PAX-FOXO1 fusion gene product. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the phenomenon of a differential effect of the same gene from different parents?

A female patient presented with fatigue. Routine complete blood count analysis showed hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, MCV 60fL, and RBC count of 5.2 million. A peripheral smear showed microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the next best investigation for this patient?

A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, arthralgia particularly in the hands, and a recent history of impotence. He has a bronze tint to his skin. His liver function tests show elevated transaminases, and his ferritin level is significantly elevated. His family history is notable for a brother who required liver transplantation due to liver failure of unknown cause. Which genetic mutation is most commonly associated with this patient's condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Mutation in the HFE gene
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Mutation in the HFE gene

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoes a liver biopsy for a lesion suspected to be focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) based on imaging studies. She has no significant medical history and normal liver function tests. Which special stain would be most useful in confirming the diagnosis of FNH in this patient?
Which of the following is correctly matched?

A 55-year-old man presents with fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss over the past 3 months. Physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 120,000/mm³, hemoglobin of 10.0 g/dL, and a platelet count of 550,000/mm³. A peripheral blood smear reveals numerous immature myeloid cells. A bone marrow biopsy shows hypercellularity with granulocytic hyperplasia, and cytogenetic testing confirms the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (t[9;22]), consistent with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). Which of the following factors is associated with a poorer prognosis in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Spleen size below the costal margin

questions.correct_answer: D. Presence of additional cytogenetic abnormalities
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Presence of additional cytogenetic abnormalities

questions.text: A patient undergoes a biopsy of a lung mass with the histology shown in the image. Which of the following immunohistochemical results would be most typical of the lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: INSM1+, chromogranin+, CK7+ diffuse, p40+, Ki67 low

options.label: B
options.text: INSM1+, chromogranin-, CK7+ diffuse, p40+, Ki67 high

options.label: C
options.text: INSM1-, chromogranin+, CK7- punctate, p40+, Ki67 high

options.label: D
options.text: INSM1+, chromogranin+, CK7- punctate, p40-, Ki67 high

questions.correct_answer: D. INSM1+, chromogranin+, CK7- punctate, p40-, Ki67 high
questions.explanation: Ans. D) INSM1+, chromogranin+, CK7- punctate, p40-, Ki67 high.

questions.text: A man with a renal disease presents to the clinic with worsening fatigue and muscle weakness. Further studies reveal increased lipid peroxidation products and decreased glutathione levels in his blood. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely contributing to his ongoing cellular injury?
Which of the following is most appropriate component for reducing the risk of graft verus host disease?

All of the following statements about proto-oncogenes are true except? 1. BRCA1 is an oncogene. 2. HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer. 3. EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer. 4. c-MYC is a tumour suppressor gene.

A young 20-year-old footballer tragically collapsed and was subsequently rushed to the hospital. Despite all efforts, the medical team could not save him, and he was pronounced deceased. The autopsy image provided gives us important information to investigate the cause of his untimely passing. What can be the most likely cause of death?

options.label: A
options.text: Valvular heart disease due to Rheumatic Heart Disease

options.label: B
options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia

options.label: C
options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden cardiac death due to atherosclerosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia

questions.text: A patient presents with an acute episode of hemolyis after drug ingestion. His peripheral smear is given along sides. Which of the following statements accurately describe the effects of Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency? 1. Decrease in reduced glutathione 2. Decreased NADPH 3. Decreased lipid peroxidation 4. Increased RBC membrane damage
A 60 year old patient with enlargement of the abdomen has enlarged ovaries and so she undergoes a histopathological examination. Which of the following tumors shows the finding depicted in the image?
Which of the following statements are true about hereditary spherocytosis?

options.label: A
options.text: It takes 1-2 years for gall stones to develop

options.label: B
options.text: Splenectomy is not protective against developing gall stones

options.label: C
